>>179484438
Yes but think how deep the tinkering would need to go for complete “free will”. You would first need to bracket any sort of category or template that your brain is imposing on your own sensory experience. Sort of like when people have a stroke and their mind loses the ability to organise sense data into memorised sets of things and people can no longer tell what any of the information they are receiving is meant to be, because no unconscious programming is organising and parsing it into templates and structures. You intend a “tree” based on your concept of a tree. You passively absorb millions of intentions like this through life and use them to interpret immediate sensory information. A good example for a social or historical equivalent is walking into a church. Imagine you go in with no frame of reference for anything you are seeing on a passive level- all of it would cease to make any sense at all. Your every thought and inclination on a very basic level is axiomatic and pre programmed, and on top of that massively influenced by the language you speak, the culture you grow up in, the people around you. What your brain isn’t already forcing you to think or do it is actively sponging from your surroundings. This idea that people can self create or really free themselves mentally and determine their own choices entirely uninfluenced is completely impossible. Everything you think and do is referring to innate evolutionary stocks of concepts you HAVE TO see the world through, and then outside influences acting on you on top of that. If you just view eywa as a living embodiment of nature, the free will thing makes no sense. It’s like saying that you didn’t design your own body and mind in some pre existent totally uninfluenced void, ergo you aren’t free. That’s a high standard for freedom.

I agree on the matter of the nature of Eywa, an organism that seems to shepherd live on Pandora to a point of equilibrium between all the agents involved in the system. >but that's not going to fit everyone
it used to fit far more people than it does now, all across the western world, in places where welfare spending differed wildly.

>Yeah if you're an immigrant and you're escaping a shit country you'll be glad to buy into those values of giving up your individuality
Individuality is a dangerous concept (which is not to say it is entirely without some merit). Enlightenment Liberalism got it wrong: We're not free-born individuals who form social contracts based on consent. We're a social/tribal species born into obligations and responsibilities not of our choosing who need other people (especially family) to be able to approach anything like freedom (another dangerous concept). Individuals thrive best when they have generations of momentum behind them and family support around them. To reach this state requires the values and sacrifice I mentioned.

(Btw, those immigrants are often coming from places with less welfare spending and worse public services than the US)

The problem in the West is since the 60s in particular, we think we *should* be able to live how ever we want, we *should* be able decide for ourselves what the good life is rather than rely on inherited wisdom arrived at through generations of trial and error, we *should* be able to pursue pleasure, to live in the now, to chase selfish dreams or lay idle, to sleep with who we want, to imbibe whatever substance we want - and all of these personal choices should lead to roughly equal, fair outcomes.

But we can't. Even in socialist states like the USSR & China they couldn't. It's unhealthy to think we should be able to live like that.

I'm all for a film showing how bad things are, but the diagnosis (lack of adequate social spending) at best only tells half the story, and at worst encourages/reinforces the view that values don't really matter, or shouldn't matter.

Even with better public spending it would be imperative to encourage people to adopt traditional values.

I see that you're trying to argue his struggle running around trying to stop the memory erasure was merely a way to pad the runtime or something. You're wrong about this too.
During all those scenes we learn how Joel and Clementine actually met for the first time, we learn everything about how their relationship started, progressed and fell apart. Interspersed with this we learn bits about Joel's childhood. Finally we see Joel and Clementine at the final memory saying goodbye maybe forever, before deciding to meet at montauk. It implies that Clementine had the same conversation in her mind with Joel during her memory erasure. Although it's implied that she didn't fight it as much as Joel did when the technician is so puzzled by what's happening with Joel.

All of this is extremely relevant to the movie and needs to be there. Now when we hear the recordings at the end, we have visual imagery to back it up because in those memory scenes we actually saw what Joel and Egirl are complaining about. We understand why they erased their memories, we understand what the consequences could potentially be if they began a relationship again.

There's nothing to get and it's a straightforward kidnapping story. However, if you want to dive deeper then it's just a criticism of both evil and imprisoning others (even if it's justified).
For example, someone's daughter is kidnapped and kept prisoner. That's like the worst thing that can happen, no? Then you realise that the kidnapper and the person who lost their daughter have each others children so you begin to question right and wrong. Obviously Keller is less wrong because the other side forced his hand by taking his daughter and he's just fighting back.
Moral of the story is to not kidnap people because it's like the worst thing you can do. Killing someone isn't even as bad as imprisoning them because you can't suffer if you're dead. That's why Keller trapped Alex and he didn't kill him.

>If ever there was a motherfucker who needed a biopic it's CWC

Never going to happen. The intersection of people willing to touch the topic and having the resources to pull it off is basically non-existent. Even not considering that, how would you market a CWC movie? Sure, this board might find it funny, but everybody else would see it as something that simply makes fun of a mentally ill person. Also, what would the movie be about anyway? Chris's life doesn't really have a narrative arc. Two hours of having cyber-sex with 13-year-old boys, playing with legos, trooning out randomly in the middle of it, and then the movie just kind of ends with him getting sent to the nuthouse.

The only option would be to sanitize the events to the point where they become unrecognizable. For example, Sonichu is a big part of his identity, but Sega and Nintendo would instantly sure the shit out of anyone who tried to adapt it. The only reason they haven't gone after CWC is because they know that suing a retard would be bad PR.

>Grant was at the Adler Theater in Davenport, Iowa, on the afternoon of Saturday, November 29, 1986, preparing for his performance in A Conversation with Cary Grant when he was taken ill; he had been feeling unwell as he arrived at the theater. Basil Williams photographed him there and thought that he still looked his usual suave self, but he noticed that he seemed very tired and that he stumbled once in the auditorium. Williams recalls that Grant rehearsed for half an hour before "something seemed wrong" all of a sudden, and he disappeared backstage. Grant was taken back to the Blackhawk Hotel where he and his wife had checked in, and a doctor was called and discovered that Grant was having a massive stroke, with a blood pressure reading of 210 over 130. Grant refused to be taken to the hospital. The doctor recalled: "The stroke was getting worse. In only fifteen minutes he deteriorated rapidly. It was terrible watching him die and not being able to help. But he wouldn't let us." By 8:45p.m., Grant had slipped into a coma and was taken to St. Luke's Hospital in Davenport, Iowa.[347] He spent 45 minutes in the emergency room before being transferred to intensive care. He died at 11:22p.m., aged 82.[348]
>"Death? Of course I think of it. But I don't want to dwell on it... I think the thing you think about when you're my age is how you're going to do it and whether you'll behave well. " - Cary Grant, 9 years prior

>>179475117
i meant just developing the special effects, the script, the sets, the screenplay, the costumes, the editing, the everyday logistics of the shoot, behind-the-scenes shenanigans involving financing. it was a full-time project for kubrick and it was blazing a new path, not a formulaic movie by any means.
as far as eyes wide shut, i think this is were kubrick's perfectionism got the better of him. the original traumnovelle TV movie of 1969 basically achieved 70% or 80% percent of what Kubrick intended, obviously with much humbler production design and means, but just the acting is much more convincing in Traumnovelle. Eyes wide shut feels very stiff and overacted in comparison. i'm open-minded to the idea that kubrick inserted a lot of symbolism and subtext into the movie, but that is kind of in vain if the film doesn't work in its essential elements and for me ultimately it doesn't.

Second Officer Lightoller described the feeling of "a thousand knives" being driven into his body as he entered the sea.[182] Sudden immersion into freezing water typically causes death within minutes, either from cardiac arrest, uncontrollable breathing of water, or cold shock (not, as commonly believed, from hypothermia);[184] almost all of those in the water died of cardiac arrest or other bodily reactions to freezing water within 15–30 minutes.[185] Only 13 of them were helped into the lifeboats, even though these had room for almost 500 more people.[186]

>Those in the lifeboats were horrified to hear the sound of what Lawrence Beesley called "every possible emotion of human fear, despair, agony, fierce resentment and blind anger mingled – I am certain of those – with notes of infinite surprise, as though each one were saying, 'How is it possible that this awful thing is happening to me? That I should be caught in this death trap?'"[187] Jack Thayer compared it to the sound of "locusts on a summer night", while George Rheims, who jumped moments before Titanic sank, described it as "a dismal moaning sound which I won't ever forget; it came from those poor people who were floating around, calling for help. It was horrifying, mysterious, supernatural."[188]
>The noise of the people in the water screaming, yelling, and crying was a tremendous shock to the occupants of the lifeboats, many of whom had up to that moment believed that everyone had escaped before the ship sank. As Beesley later wrote, the cries "came as a thunderbolt, unexpected, inconceivable, incredible. No one in any of the boats standing off a few hundred yards away can have escaped the paralysing shock of knowing that so short a distance away a tragedy, unbelievable in its magnitude, was being enacted, which we, helpless, could in no way avert or diminish."[187]

its complicated but the company had to cover up that the titanic was damaged by a collision with a naval ship for insurance reasons (and to save face for the navy) so they welded a plate over the OLYMPIC label with TITANIC (putting the name on a plate instead of the actual hull of the ship isn't normal) so that they could repair the real Titanic without anyone noticing. There are reports from people who were on the 'Titanic' who said that it was the Olympic, they even had life-rings with the name on it. Considering that the company would sue survivors for saying the ship broke in half (because it put the question of structural integrity into question) I would not put it past them to pull some greedy shit like this.

Even in the clip I posted though? The guy has no reason to be putting himself out there like he is there, he has no reason to be making himself vulnerable. He's purely doing that out of genuine fatherly feeling. Same with some of his dumb scriptwriting stuff, some of his conversations with Adriana, he actually did want to make something of himself. He even says some confused shit here and there about valuing loyalty, and really means it.

I don't see anything innately evil in him, I see that more in characters like Paulie who are just pure low IQ sociopaths who have filtered into the mob life because it was the first thing that came along and gave them some purpose and success, but now they're stuck in it, just like they'd be stuck in whatever menial job they would have gotten if fate had turned out differently (but then, again, they'd probably be normal family men).

I get what you're saying and I think you're right, but you're describing the extreme end of the spectrum of the show's condemnation of the mob life. What you're saying is true, especially when used as a counter to people who think it's just "lol mobsters are badass" - but to me it goes beyond just, look, Chris isn't badass, he's degenerate. To me the show is "about":
>these guys are just jobbers, as miserable as everybody else
>even what they do is basically a form of the "american dream" and it's as much a fraud as any other form
>not only that, it's outcompeted by basic bitch white collar crime and even just white collar jobs like doctors
>the mob life objectively sucks, BUT it also offers things not found in basic bitch white collar or anonymous menial life: a sense of tradition, a community of fellow men, a "warrior" lifestyle, the sense of not being a domesticated animal, etc.
>nevertheless it's dying anyway, they're all just being chewed up by it, etc.
However I do strongly agree that this is fiction, and most criminals, including these kinds IRL, are just 80IQ sociopath brutes.

Yeah but he sees himself as a soldier, he sees it as "just business," he sees it as valid in the mob life to kill people who insult you, he is also an immature child who is allowed to be a murdering brute and kill random waiters for bothering him, so of course he takes the path of least resistance and remains an immature murdering brute. All of these things coexist with his desire to be good and see himself as good, like any human being, except maybe total degenerates like Paulie who operate at a purely animal level.

That's why it's so sad, because he's trapped in a hell that has grown around him, his own entire personality and everything about him is a torture chamber for the sparks of human goodness in him. He's doomed to either suppress them, snuff them out, or live in perpetual internal contradiction, drowning it with degeneracy and drugs until he eventually dies. Tony is slightly different since his thing isn't innate dopey goodness being smothered but higher potential, but same basic idea.
